intro: Paraspalathus psoraleoides, commonly known as the narrow-leafed broomrape, is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its slender, leafless stems and small, inconspicuous flowers. The plant typically grows in open, disturbed habitats and is often found in association with grasses and other herbaceous plants. Its reproductive strategy involves producing small, dry fruits that release seeds through wind dispersal. Due to its specialized lifestyle, it plays a unique role in ecosystem dynamics as a parasite.
